1468310612342198272.text: 80 years later, the memories of these men, and all those impacted in the attack on Pearl Harbor, lives on. And it’s Rep. Gallagher's hope that as we reflect on these stories of service and sacrifice, we’re all inspired to conduct ourselves in a way that’s worthy of their service.

1468310611327127561.text:
Earl Wallen; Private 1st Class; Marine Corps; USS California.

Mr. Wallen of Pensaukee attended St. Norbert College for a year before enlisting. For his heroic actions St. Norbert granted him an honorary degree and American Legion Post 11 in Green Bay bears his name.

1468310610387640333.text:
Joseph Muhofski; Radioman 3rd Class; Navy; USS Pennsylvania.
 
Mr. Muhofski was born and raised in Kewaunee, where he is laid to rest with his parents, Joseph and Lucy, at Holy Rosary Cemetery.

1468310609334784001.text:
Malachy Cashen; Corporal; Army; Wheeler Field.
 
Mr. Cashen attended School in Outagamie County while in the service, and was laid to rest in the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific in Hawaii.

1468310608391061510.text:
Laxton Newman; Aviation Machinist’s Mate 3rd Class; Navy; Kaneohe NAS.
 
Mr. Newman was from Crivitz. He was awarded a Silver Star Medal for his service and later had a Buckley-class destroyer escort named after him, the USS Newman.

1468310607438954517.text:
Herbert McLaughlin; Private; Army; Hickman Field.
 
Mr. Mclaughln was from Shawano. The VFW in Shawano is currently named after him. He is tragically still missing in action but is honored at Honolulu Memorial in Hawaii.

1468310606323363845.text:
Philip Gazecki, Ensign; Navy (reserve); USS Arizona.
 
Mr. Gazecki attended Menasha High, where he was the salutatorian of his class. He later attended Harvard and developed a paint that was used to keep barnacles from attaching to ships in World War II.

1468310604985290755.text:
William Bruesewitz, Seaman 1st Class; Navy USS Oklahoma.
 
Mr. Bruesewitz was born in Clinton and lived in Appleton while serving. His body was not identified until 2018, and he was eventually laid to rest in Arlington National Cemetery on the 77th anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

1370075371102744576.text: We must act with a sense of urgency to better defend our nation, from federal and state networks, to our large corporations and main street small businesses, to every American, in cyber space. If we fail to rise to the moment, we will soon regret it.

1370075370100232202.text: Over the last year, @SenAngusKing and I have spent a lot of time referring to Solarium as a 9/11 Commission before 9/11. But the past few months have challenged this framing. The cyber disruption is already here, and it is happening on a near daily basis.

1370075369223639040.text: We need to explore how we can provide liability protections for companies to respond in real time against cyberattacks while doubling down on Solarium recommendations to expand federal network defense and public-private collaboration.

1370075368267333632.text: Yet these steps will only help if we action them. We need nominations for the National Cyber Director and CISA Director yesterday. We need a declaratory policy when it comes cyberattacks, and we need to signal that we will enforce it ruthlessly.

1370075367323623435.text: Thanks to the CSC's tireless efforts and bipartisan collaboration on both sides of the Hill, the FY 21 NDAA was the most significant cyber legislation in US history. We created the National Cyber Director, strengthened CISA, and took steps to ensure continuity of our economy.

1370075366358933504.text: Since then, the US has experienced not only the pandemic, but two catastrophic cyberattacks. As we learn more about the recent Microsoft Exchange attacks, I am increasingly concerned about the damage, especially since criminal groups can exploit this vulnerability.

1370075365247483906.text: THREAD ➡️ One year ago today, the @CyberSolarium unveiled its recommendations on Capitol Hill. Little did we know at the time how cyber would become even more important in our day to day lives (or that it would be our last chance to gather in person in the foreseeable future).

1355161941086527489.text: This is not a cheap partisan jab: I made this exact same criticism of the previous administration and voted against Trump's use of emergency executive authority because it ignored Congress's clear constitutional authority to appropriate money. https://t.co/oWvPwwPLBf

1355161940105060355.text: President Biden is blowing through norms with the sheer volume and scope of these executive orders. That's wrong. But it shouldn't be surprising. The next president, regardless of party, will probably do the same thing.

1355161939165507589.text: That hurts the economy, it sows confusion among citizens, and it often helps the powerful and the connected at the expense of everybody else. That, in turn, raises the stakes for each election - because seemingly everything turns on the outcome.

1355161938217594880.text: In the short term, this behavior wins the praise of partisans. But in the longer term it creates instability and chaos in our constitutional system. Every single election, the disposition of the entire federal government changes on a dime, across a wide range of issues.

1355161937286488070.text: So what happens when Congress decides not to play its part? First, the other branches step in to fill the space. Courts legislate from the bench. The president and bureaucracy tackle problems and policy however they like.

1355161936355340288.text: Our constitution is designed to have Congress at the center. We are supposed to be making laws and directing the government. The president and the federal courts are empowered to check Congress, but they are not supposed to replace our legislative authority.

1355161935453560834.text: This is THE biggest problem with Congress today. You may have heard that America has three coequal branches. This is wrong. Congress is the dominant branch of government. We are the first branch, and we have the most power over the other two.

1355161934488809472.text: Put simply: Congress. Every president issues guidance to the executive branch. That's normal. But when Congress passes bad, vague, or imprecise laws, it opens up space that executive orders fill. In other words, Congress enables presidential discretion.

But far from the straw man it is often portrayed as, I write in @WSJopinion that Cold War thinking offers a judicious and adaptable framework for our time. https://t.co/wyFKX3f6K8

1269387408325345293.text: We’d all like to see our allies make larger investments to support our collective defense. But this is not the way to do that. I urge the administration to reconsider this decision. https://t.co/YifymbvN0c

1269387406085705728.text: Cutting our forces in Germany not only reduces our forward presence and our ability to deter aggression in Europe, but it will end up costing us more. Troops leaving Germany will have to go somewhere, and wherever they go, they won’t have the benefit of German financial support.

1269387403879481346.text: To deny, we must be forward. Our forces in Germany are a critical lynchpin of this forward presence. Not only does Germany have unparalleled supporting infrastructure, but it provides millions of dollars to help fund the US presence.

1269387401698447364.text: The National Defense Strategy rightly prioritizes these forward forces today. Rather than punish adversary aggression after the fact, the NDS emphasizes a posture of deterrence by denial, which seeks to deny adversaries their attempted conquests in the first place.

1269387399542571012.text: The war was a terrible lesson that American needed to defend forward. No longer could we sit back across the ocean and let the storm clouds gather. In the ensuing decades, our forward presence won the Cold War by successfully deterring a Soviet invasion of Western Europe.

1269387396082290689.text: The extraordinary sacrifices made on that day of days did not come out of thin air. In the 1930s, deterrence failed, our adversaries saw a free world unwilling to impose costs on aggression, and democracies were late to mobilize against the Nazi war machine.

1269387391938199561.text: THREAD ➡️ 76 years ago today, tens of thousands of Americans, along with our allies, displayed unparalleled courage on the beaches and causeways of Normandy, beginning the long process of liberating Europe from Nazi rule.

1264248139755728900.text: Is a former Senator and US Ambassador comparing the President to Hitler on the state channel of a communist dictatorship that has put more than a million of its own citizens into concentration camps gross? Of course. But that's only part of the problem.

1264248137511849984.text: Individuals, corporations, or countries that adapt pro-CCP talking points and policies receive lucrative rewards. Those who challenge the Party orthodoxy are punished. We’ve seen this time and again. The CCP relies on foreign elites to promote its interests.

1264248134768758784.text: The Party’s core identity, as well as that of its leaders, is tied to these types of influence operations, which the Party calls United Front work. The Party works through elites in capitals worldwide to advance this agenda, connecting economic incentives w/ political compliance.

1264248131748802561.text: The CCP credits its underground influence operations for playing a decisive role in its victory in the civil war. 1264248128741539841.text: While many of the details in the story were shocking, the bottom line shouldn't have been surprising. The CCP was born to take advantage of the swamp. 1260267294195879936.text: As a Marine, you learn to ride to the sound of the guns. When setting goals as a civilian, exercise that same mentality. Once you’re discharged, go where the action is. Push yourself outside your comfort zone & use the skills you’ve learned to achieve what you want. #VeteransChat https://t.co/wiMR7YmX0G

1260265706865688578.text: Even with a strong support network, I skipped simple tasks and didn’t take advantage of all the resources available to me at the time.

1260265671130337280.text: I would’ve looked for more help. When I discharged, I was eager to start my life. But I didn’t realize just how many resources were available to me in the form of VA benefits and local VSOs. #VeteransChat https://t.co/1FOlrPo8U2

1260263675920822273.text: Incidentally, this ethos of selfless service is what makes veterans such an asset in any workplace. We can work in teams to get difficult jobs done. #VeteransChat

1260263644895621123.text: Officers eat last. We have a duty to help others, to look out for our subordinates first. Particularly those of us who have benefitted from great mentorship in our careers, I believe we have a duty to pay that back. #VeteransChat https://t.co/tpumyLNrjJ

1260261396740280321.text: Be open, be honest, and let your mentor know when you need help. Your mentor has been in your shoes — he or she knows the ins and outs of transitioning back to civilian life and can show you the ropes through even the littlest of matters. #VeteransChat https://t.co/2otQHdBd74

1260260106979151874.text: You’ll quickly learn there’s a lot of help out there — whether it’s job assistance or free donut Fridays at a local business.

1260260102629732353.text: That’s why I firmly believe that the best resource for veterans are their fellow service members. When you get back, connect with your veteran service officer, your local veteran service organization, or a non-profit that focuses on helping veterans.

1260260060267233282.text: Don't be embarrassed to ask for help. Drop the tough guy/gal act and seek assistance (i.e. leadership principle: know yourself and seek self-improvement). There are many resources available to us as veterans — we just have to be willing to ask and learn about them. #VeteransChat https://t.co/E8pTTnCDUh

1260257567969861635.text: As veterans, we have incredible skill sets and leadership traits from our time in service. But it’s on us to translate those skills into success in the civilian world. #VeteransChat

1260257541122134020.text: The belief that our military experience will fit nicely with every civilian job is a common blind spot, in large part because not every civilian company understands fully the nature of military experience or the specific skills we gain from our military occupational specialties. https://t.co/uWjuj0cvEi

1260256342801027077.text: Often we don't realize how overwhelming some of the basics of civilian life can be until after we are discharged. That alone can be a difficult adjustment. #VeteransChat

1260256333414182914.text: Consider how many choices the military makes for you when you're on active duty. Basic things like monthly financial planning, getting a loan for a house, or starting to save for your kids' school may not even cross your radar if you're living on base and deploying all the time.

1260256299159347207.text: Recently discharged veterans, myself included, tend to think that the transition to civilian life will be easy. For many, it’s not. Veterans should accept advice during their transition and understand that civilian life comes with challenges we just don't face in the military. https://t.co/Ng9UHcHemD

1260254393213083651.text: Veterans in my area do a remarkable job of helping others find peer mentors. Groups like the NEW Battalion are “the missing link for the transitioning process” and show how veterans support each other as civilians just as they did in combat. #VeteransChat https://t.co/TvQIcKrRoZ

1260254373340299265.text: As veterans, we have different experiences and speak a different language than our civilian counterparts — that can be a difficult adjustment. 1250849386432811008.text: 10. Find strength in our community. Northeast Wisconsin’s strength is the quality and heart of this community. We all need to do our part to help our neighbors, support local nonprofits and businesses, and get through this the way we do best—together.

1250849381953257472.text: 9. Reopen state parks, with caveats. More than ever, this is a time where Wisconsinites need to be able to get fresh air and a dose of sanity. Whether it’s closing parking lots, maintaining limited hours, or keeping a skeleton ranger crew on hand, we need to get creative.

1250849379721916418.text: 8. Come up with a bipartisan election plan, now. The August primary will be here before we know it, and soon after, November. We should start immediately planning to ensure they go off without a hitch — the legitimacy of our democracy is at stake.

1250849377339543558.text: 7. Focus on our dairy farmers. Wisconsin’s dairy sector desperately needs help. Federal funds are a start, but until we break the bottleneck at the processor level, we will be stuck seeing rationing at grocery stores while our farmers are forced to dump excess milk.

1250849375246602240.text: 6. School’s in for summer. Our students can’t afford to lose a half year or more of schooling. High schools should consider more online classes, while younger classes may want to make use of empty high schools to move to in person instruction in significantly smaller groups.

1250849372440584192.text: 5. Continue to support small business. Congress desperately needs to add resources to the Paycheck Protection Program, which ran through $350 billion in two weeks. Every day we delay putting more money into this program is a day we risk seeing hardworking businesses go under.

1250849368955146241.text: 4. Maintain strict social distancing for the most at risk populations, including the elderly and those with compromised immune systems. We’ll have to continue pitching in to help these individuals, as they may not be able to return to normal until a vaccine is widely available.

1250849366845329410.text: 3. Develop responsible contact tracing and antibody analysis for individuals who have been infected. The private sector is doing great work in this regard, and we need to leverage these resources and put them to work on behalf of Wisconsinites.

1250849364588797954.text: 2. Testing, testing, and more testing. The sooner our labs and hospitals have the ability to provide quick and accessible tests to a majority of Wisconsinites, the sooner we can end the lockdown.

1250849362063884288.text: 1. We need a bipartisan task force charged with creating a plan to reopen WI. The task force would bring everyone to the table—state authorities, healthcare experts, businesses large and small, first responders, and educators—and get to work immediately. There’s no time to waste.

1250849335773986817.text: THREAD ➡️ Later today the President will unveil his blueprint to reopen the economy. 1247922016033832961.text: This is no time for partisan theatrics. It's time to continue what is working, fix what isn't, support our neighbors, and get through this as we always have--as a community.

1247922013794177025.text: But while we need to fix these pressing issues, we also can’t let this distract from defeating this disease. There aren’t enough dollars to print if we fail to contain this virus, and any additional action should surge more resources and support to the frontlines of the fight.

1247922011688632321.text: I'm glad to see initial reports indicating Congress could add to the pool of PPP resources available for small businesses. Across NEW, small businesses are desperately awaiting the help they need to meet payroll, make rent, and survive another day. Relief cannot come soon enough.

1247922009419534338.text: Third, despite Congressional intent, SBA has severely restricted non-payroll loan forgiveness in order to maximize the number of businesses that can benefit from the program. To fix this, Congress should add more funding AND provide more flexibility in how the loans can be used.

1247922007284613127.text: Second, we need to support startups—some of which may help prevent future pandemics—by ensuring there’s no confusion around the SBA's affiliation rules. SBA should ensure lenders have the clarity they need to expeditiously make loans to innovative startups.

1247922004839346182.text: At the same time, we still have to address outstanding issues. For one, some lenders are unsure whether PPP eligibility definitions exclude many NEW dairy farms from receiving support. SBA should immediately clarify that dairy farms do not have to meet SBA’s NAICS codes.

1247922002100391936.text: While anything on the scale of the CARES Act will take time, Northeast Wisconsin's small businesses do not have weeks to wait. We must be laser-focused on processing PPP loans as quickly as possible in order to get cash into the hands of those who need it most--yesterday.

1247705353208369152.text: As a maritime nation, our physical security begins and ends with command of the seas. Maritime superiority is not a birthright but a hard-won status we can’t surrender. The task ahead for the Navy and advocates in Congress is not easy, but it is simple: don’t give up the ship.

1247705351157407745.text: In other words, we need a course correction, at flank speed. Front page incidents are starting to pile up, taking with them close to a generation of seasoned leaders. Morale is down. Budgets are inadequate. Enemies are investing heavily in hard power, particularly seapower.

1247705348393381891.text: Even as investigations continue, the Navy must turn the page. That starts with Senate-confirmed leadership at the top, a commitment to transparency, and a willingness to communicate a simple vision of geopolitically-informed, integrated American seapower directly to the public.

1247705345281134592.text: While I am grateful for his service, it was no longer tenable for Secretary Modly to lead the Navy. 1241537981330214914.text: This is an unprecedented crisis that will require unprecedented action. But that doesn’t mean we can allow the relief package to become an Easter basket full of carveouts for corporate & special interests. In this bill we have to put small businesses & vulnerable Americans first.

1241537977639219201.text: 3) A focus on community banks. In 2008, one idea that worked was allowing the FDIC to extend unlimited insurance for transaction accounts. This helped prevent a run on small banks and sent a badly needed message that money is safe with local lenders. We should replicate that now.

1241537974438854656.text: 2) Immediate and sustained aid to the most vulnerable among us. Paid sick leave is great, but the process is convoluted and doesn’t help those getting laid off. We need to get checks to working Americans now and expand unemployment insurance programs for those who need them.

1241537971175804934.text: 1) A loan program that provides immediate relief to small businesses. These would be paid over a long-term period at 0% interest and allow businesses to delay initial payments up to 3 months, giving employers access to the cash they need to get through the worst of this crisis.

1124020600744415233.text: We should all ask our elected representatives what they are doing in light of the CCP challenge, and these officials should have a good response. This is the greatest international challenge facing the free world. It’s time we start acting like it.

1124020600119414785.text: But for all the progress, we could still choose to bury our head in the sand about the challenge before us. Open conflict with China is avoidable, if we play our cards right, but competition is inevitable. In fact, it’s already here, and it’s happening on a daily basis.

1124020599314104326.text: We’ve come a long way over the past two years in waking up to the threat posed by the CCP. We’ve begun rebuilding our military, we’ve strengthened safeguards against weaponized foreign investment, and we’re in the middle of a major diplomatic campaign about 5G.

1124020598475296768.text: Responding to the CCP’s aggression is not a partisan issue. But it will be a defining issue. Across the free world, politicians left, right, & center will be forced to confront the reality that our democracies are facing their greatest challenge in decades.

1124020597804150784.text: To get it out of the way, the CCP leaders overseeing the concentration camps of Xinjiang, where a million or more are being detained largely on account of their religion, are in fact, “bad folks.” But here’s where things get interesting.

1124020597028261891.text: Biden has been roundly criticized, and for good reason. But his comments--and the reaction to them--are worth thinking about further.

1124020596382273536.text: Yesterday, former VP Biden said that China’s leaders are “not bad folks” and that China does not pose a competitive challenge to the US. This is dangerous thinking, and it’s the logic that led to decades of bipartisan neglect while the CCP worked tirelessly to overtake us.

1123597623745757187.text: You have a chance to do the right thing and alleviate the suffering of your people and your families--those you have sworn an oath to protect. When a legitimate democracy has been restored, we look forward to having you return to the profession of arms.”

1115991624159571968.text: This is why I introduced HR 1522, the Congressional and Executive Lobbying Ban Act. The bill would prevent former Members of Congress, senior executive branch political appointees, and retired flag and general officers from registering as foreign agents.

1115991623610052608.text: More broadly, senior officials across government should not be able to shop their connections and access on behalf of foreign countries, especially adversaries.

1115991623018717185.text: Since apparently lobbying on behalf of a “foreign power” or an “agent of a foreign power” like the CCP does not come with automatic FARA status, it’s time to change the law.

1110996220321955846.text: I hope we can learn from this. We have enough problems without inventing bogeymen—either from those who repeatedly peddled the collusion narrative or from those who baselessly attacked Mueller’s integrity. We need to work together to ensure this does not become business as usual.

1110996219667582976.text: Key individuals who should have known better lied to the public, and in doing so, did serious harm to our national security. They disgraced themselves and, unfortunately, damaged the reputations of their institutions and the many honorable men and women in the IC.

1110996219063664640.text: As a former intelligence officer, I’m gravely concerned by the way the intelligence community (IC) became politicized over the past two years. Officials like Comey, Clapper, Brennan, and Schiff eroded public trust in our IC by wading too deeply into politics and innuendo.

1110996218551955456.text: The simple fact is our media did itself no favors over the past two years. All too often, it delved into clickbait conspiracy rather than objective journalism. This can’t continue, because we really do need the media to hold politicians accountable.

1110996217947922432.text: Just imagine for a minute being so opposed to the President that you actively wished he was disloyal to the country and was an agent of a hostile foreign power. It’s crazy and demonstrates the extent to which shallow political combat has become our new national religion.

1110996217083949056.text: Which leads to another ugly truth. All Americans should be glad there was no collusion. But you wouldn’t know it by all the disappointed faces on cable news, some of whom are now questioning the integrity of Mueller and Barr.

1110996216463216641.text: Part of getting to work means coming to terms with the ugly truths underlying this saga and ensuring something like this never happens again. That means we not only need full disclosure of the report, but also the process that gave rise to the investigation in the first place.

1110996215896961025.text: Obviously we need the full report, but AG Barr made his conclusions clear. We need to stop with collusion conspiracy theories and the efforts to change the 2016 election, and get to work on the real problems facing this country.

1110996214819024896.text: Since day one, I’ve emphasized the need for a full and impartial investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Many of my Democratic colleagues called on Republicans to put aside party and stand on principle with Mueller. We did that. Now they must do the same.

1110996213258694656.text: I've spent the past few days observing the reactions to the findings of Special Counsel Mueller's investigation. I wanted to share my candid thoughts on Mueller's report below. ⬇️

1096225304476110848.text: Conservatives celebrating the emergency declaration should pause and consider the following:

1096225078247915521.text:
The appropriators released a 1100+ page omnibus bill after midnight today. 

We suspended (i.e. violated) the rules to vote on it less than 24 hours later with no real deliberation or debate.

1096225020995620864.text:
Why do we have a Congress?

Presumably we have a Congress to deliberate, debate, and legislate. When it comes to border security, Congress has done none of these things.

1070015693951852544.text: Just as importantly, our @NATO allies have released a unanimous statement concurring with the administration’s assessment of Russia’s material breach. So let’s be clear: this is not a unilateral step away from arms control. This is a consensus finding coordinated with our allies.

1070015585294188550.text: Today, @SecPompeo delivered an unequivocal finding that Russia’s actions constitute a material breach of INF. If Russia fails to verifiably return to its obligations under the agreement, in 60 days, the US will suspend its compliance with the treaty.

1070015514951467008.text: Recognizing these realities, my amendment to the FY19 NDAA gave @POTUS until January to make a final determination of whether Russia is in material breach of its INF obligations. In the event of a positive material breach determination, the amendment set a path to exit the treaty

1070015339478573056.text: Meanwhile, China has never been part of the treaty and has amassed an arsenal over 2,000 ballistic and cruise missiles—about 95% of which fall under INF ranges. These missiles are far cheaper than our ships and planes, meaning we are increasingly priced out of the competition.

1070015257115004929.text: Although we did not realize it at the time, we know from former Obama administration officials that Russia began testing INF-prohibited ground-launched cruise missiles in 2008. Every year since 2014, the @StateDept has found Russia to be in violation of its INF obligations.

1070015101858660352.text: .@SecPompeo deserves enormous credit for today’s announcement. Not only are we moving forward on INF in a way that makes clear Russia is the party acting in bad faith, but we are doing so in close coordination with our @NATO allies. A quick recap:

1052647678797066241.text: Whatever the answers, what is clear is that demands on the Navy are only set to grow in the future. Let's not let perfect be the enemy of good. Let's get building. The Navy the nation needs is the biggest one it can possibly build—now.

1052647347723952128.text: What's the Navy been up to in the six months since we first heard about a new assessment in March? And why will the new assessment not be ready until more than a year after the new defense strategy?

1052647219474681856.text: The problem is the way in which this is happening. In March, the Navy told us that they were planning on conducting a new force structure assessment. Then, the Navy re-announced a forthcoming new assessment just last month, due “some time” in 2019.

1052646649833644033.text: Back in December 2016, the Navy released a force structure assessment that called for a 355-ship fleet. Given the change in administration and defense strategy since then, it makes sense that the Navy wants to review the size and composition of its future fleet.

1052646508129112065.text: Thanks @JerryHendrixII. As I discussed with @hughhewitt and wrote in @RCDefense, despite clear guidance from the White House, almost halfway into the Trump administration’s first term, progress toward a 355-ship Navy has been mixed at best.
